Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an instrument for quantitative characterization of size distribution of aquatic colloids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Colloids are the most abundant particles in the ocean and other aquatic environments, and play a crucial role in the structure and functioning of these ecosystems. The PI's request funding to design and fabricate a new instrument, an Aquatic Colloidal Analyzer (ACAN), for quantitative determinations of concentration and size distribution of heterogeneous colloidal assemblages (including nanoparticles) present in aqueous suspensions. No instrumentation is presently available which provides accurate information about size distribution of polydisperse systems of aquatic colloids over a broad size range from about 10 nm to 1 Âµm. The ACAN will utilize a Nanoparticle Tracking Analysis (NTA) method, which is based on physical principles of Brownian motion and light scattering by colloids.

The ACAN measurements on unperturbed samples will provide a capability for acquiring an unprecedented wealth of scientifically new and valuable information on polydisperse assemblages of naturally occurring aquatic colloids, which cannot be obtained using present techniques. The data from these measurements will be fundamental in extending the understanding of the biogeochemistry of the ocean, the carbon cycle, satellite remote sensing of the oceans for biogeochemical and climate studies, the roles of microbes in ocean ecosystems, and atmospheric colloidal particles and their deposition into the ocean (via rainwater analysis).

Broader Impacts:

The proposed instrument has the potential to impact a broad range of environmental studies related to particle dynamics, such as biology, chemistry, optics, physics and climate science. These measurement are critical for many fields in the aquatic sciences The project would interface with the education and outreach projects with the UCSD Preuss School and the Scripps Birch Aquarium designed for K-12 students, college students, and general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Novel technology MANTA (Multi-spectral Advanced Nanoparticle Analysis) for visualization and measurements of nanoparticles in liquid samples was developed. A prototype instrument based on novel MANTA technology for nanoparticle characterization was designed and constructed. The prototype system was tested and validated with a variety of nanoparticle samples, which indicated superior accuracy in determining nanoparticle size and concentration compared with traditional techniques or other commercial devices for nanoparticle characterization. The prototype instrument is available at the Ocean Optics Research Lab, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California San Diego.

The MANTA instrument and associated software have been registered and copyrighted with the University of California San Diego Technology Transfer Office. The utility patent application describing MANTA technology was submitted to the US Patent Office. This application is pending.

The MANTA technology was presented to many communities within academia and industry with interest in nanoparticle characterization. For example, a number of presentations on MANTA technology and its potential wide-ranging applications in nanomedicine, pharmaceutical industry, nanoparticle engineering and characterization were made for many communities of interest throughout the course of the project, including FDA, NIST, Frederick National Institute for Cancer Research, Pfizer, Amgen, MedImmune, Celgene, Arcturus Therapeutics, BIND Therapeutics, Cerulean Pharma, Liquidia Technologies, Particle Sciences, nanoComposix, as well as Chemistry and Engineering laboratories within the University of California San Diego.

The start-up company MANTA Instruments Inc. was founded and the MANTA technology was commercialized by this company. The MANTA company obtained a license for this invention from the University of California San Diego. To date, the commercial version of the MANTA instrument has been purchased by researchers at two universities for the study of nanoparticles in environmental systems.

MANTA technology is expected to have broad impact on other disciplines as there is strong interest in this technology among pharmaceutical companies, biomedical research laboratories, and environmental research laboratories. It is expected that the outcomes of this project will have significant impact for advancing research and applications related to human and environmental health. In addition, the outcomes of this project including the commercialized product offered by MANTA Instruments Inc. provide wide-ranging opportunities for training and professional development of various communities within academia and industry with interest in nanotechnology, especially nanoparticle engineering and nanoparticle characterization.
